results_summary: OPE at 1.5 g/L completely inhibited fungal growth and spore germination. Ferulic and p-coumaric acids showed strong inhibitory effects, while flavonoids had limited activity, with no observed synergism between compounds.
population_specificity: Post-harvest fungal pathogens (Monilinia fructicola, Botrytis cinerea, Alternaria alternata).
effective_dosage: 1.5 g/L OPE; varying lower concentrations also tested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Orange Peel Extract (OPE) and/or Selenium (Se) on chronic non-bacterial prostatitis induced by 17β-estradiol in a rat model.
results_summary: OPE and/or Se significantly improved oxidative stress markers, antioxidant enzyme levels, inflammatory markers, and histological alterations in the prostate gland, demonstrating protective effects against chronic non-bacterial prostatitis. The combination of OPE and Se showed synergistic benefits via anti-oxidation and anti-inflammation mechanisms.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of orange peel extract (OPE) combined with glycerol for microbial lipid production using oleaginous yeast strains, particularly R. toruloides NRRL 1091, in fed-batch bioreactor processes.
results_summary: The study found that OPE, when used with glycerol in fed-batch processes, significantly boosted microbial lipid production, achieving high biomass and lipid volumetric productions (LVP). The fatty acid profiles of the lipids resembled Jatropha oil, suggesting potential for biodiesel production.
population_specificity: Oleaginous yeast strains, specifically R. toruloides NRRL 1091.
effective_dosage: Not specified (continuous supply mode at low dilution rates: 0.02 h-1 for SSF-FB and 0.01 h-1 for DSF-FB).
study_duration: 104 hours for SSF-FB; duration for DSF-FB not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of orange peel-derived activated carbon as an adsorbent material for wastewater treatment applications.
results_summary: Orange peel-derived activated carbon showed increased surface area (49.54-228.90 m² g-1) with higher acid concentration, confirming functional C-O-P groups and thermal stability. The resulting carbon foams exhibited a two-level cell structure, enhancing pore quantity.
population_specificity: Agro-industrial waste materials (orange peel and sugarcane bagasse).
effective_dosage: Not specified (acid concentrations of 45, 65, and 85 wt.% used in activation).
study_duration: Not specified (two-step activation process at 400 °C and 500 °C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if orange peel-derived activated carbon could effectively adsorb cationic and anionic dyes from wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that orange peel-derived activated carbon achieved high dye removal efficiencies (>99%) for methylene blue and methyl orange, with maximum equilibrium uptakes of 1012.10 mg/g (MO) and 382.15 mg/g (MB) using ZnCl2 and KOH activation, respectively. The adsorption mechanisms involved electrostatic binding, pi-pi interactions, hydrogen bonding, and electron donor-acceptor reactions.
population_specificity: Laboratory organic wastewater samples (~35 mg/L of MB).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorption capacities reported in mg/g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether orange peel extract (OPE) and its main compound, naringin (NR), could reduce the side effects of doxorubicin (Dox) in esophageal cancer stem cells (CSCs) both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: OPE and NR reduced cellular toxicity and apoptosis caused by Dox in vitro and maintained body weight while decreasing tumor size and oxidative stress in vivo. OPE appeared more protective than NR when combined with Dox.
population_specificity: Esophageal cancer stem cells (YM1-derived spheres) and xenograft mice tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae in producing bioethanol from orange peel as a lignocellulosic substrate.
results_summary: The engineered strain showed significantly higher cellulase activity and ethanol production (7.53 g/L) compared to wild-type S. cerevisiae (0.2 g/L) when using orange peel as a fermentation substrate. The study demonstrated a 37.7-fold increase in ethanol yield after 48 hours of fermentation.
population_specificity: Engineered Saccharomyces cerevisiae (laboratory strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biosorbent efficiency of dried orange peel for removing copper ions (Cu II) from water.
results_summary: The study found that dried orange peel effectively removed copper ions, with optimal performance at pH 6. The adsorption data fit well with Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms, and 0.1N H2SO4 was identified as the best eluent for desorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (environmental/agricultural application).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorbent dosage varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the chemical composition of orange peel affects the properties of hydrochar produced through hydrothermal treatment, for potential applications like adsorbents or fuels.
results_summary: Lignin-added feedstock yielded more hydrochar with rougher surfaces and higher BET areas, hemicellulose-aided hydrochar had denser carbonaceous microspheres and more hydroxyl groups, and cellulose-enhanced hydrochar showed diverse oxygenous groups but smaller microspheres.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study using orange peel as bio-waste).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modified waste orange peel could effectively adsorb arsenic (As(III)) from contaminated water.
results_summary: The study found that calcined magnetic orange peel composites (CMOPC) exhibited superior As(III) adsorption capacity (10.3mg/g) due to high surface area, large pore size, and active sites. The adsorbent also demonstrated good anti-interference ability, regeneration capacity, and effectiveness in treating simulated contaminated water.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions contaminated with arsenic (As(III)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-hyperglycemic, anti-hyperlipidemic, and antioxidant effects of navel orange peel hydroethanolic extract and its flavonoids (naringin and naringenin) in type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: The treatments improved insulin levels, liver glycogen content, lipid profile, and antioxidant defense while enhancing mRNA expression of insulin-related genes in diabetic rats. The extract and flavonoids showed potent anti-diabetic effects via insulinotropic and insulin-improving actions.
population_specificity: NA/STZ-induced type 2 diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of orange peel extracts (OPE) with varying polymethoxylated flavone (PMF) content on ethanol-induced tight junction dysfunction in intestinal cells.
results_summary: Xinhui-OPE, with higher PMF content, reduced lactate dehydrogenase leakage and increased glutathione reductase activity in ethanol-treated Caco-2 cells, while both OPE and flavonoid mixtures prevented ethanol-induced disruptions to tight junction proteins. Xinhui-OPE also enhanced claudin 4 and occludin protein expression, unlike Guangxi-OPE or the flavonoid mixture.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (human intestinal cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nanobiocatalysts (cellulase and pectinase immobilized magnetic nanoparticles) could enhance the extraction of carotenoidic pigments from Nagpur mandarin orange peels compared to free enzymes.
results_summary: The study found that using nanobiocatalysts increased carotenoid extraction by 8-9 fold compared to free enzymes, with optimal conditions at pH 5.0 and 50°C. The nanobiocatalysts maintained effectiveness over three reuse cycles with only a 15% drop in yield per cycle.
population_specificity: Nagpur mandarin orange peels (Citrus reticulata).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism by which 5-OH-HxMF, a compound in orange peel, inhibits adipogenesis and lipid accumulation.
results_summary: 5-OH-HxMF reduced lipid accumulation by 55-60% in a dose-dependent manner, suppressed adipogenesis-related transcription factors (PPARγ, C/EBPs), and activated AMPK and SIRT1 pathways. It was 15-20% more effective than HpMF in inhibiting lipid accumulation.
population_specificity: High-fat-induced obese mice and 3T3-L1 adipocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the "orange peel excision of gland (OPEG) technique" for treating gynecomastia, focusing on reducing operative time and complications.
results_summary: The OPEG technique demonstrated reduced operative time (60 minutes per breast), minimal complications (one small hematoma), and high patient satisfaction (95%). The method avoided residual gland and hematoma with excellent aesthetic outcomes.
population_specificity: 20 male patients (38 breasts total, 18 bilateral and 2 unilateral cases) with gynecomastia.
study_duration: Not specified (single operative session per breast).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether orange peel waste (OPW) could be used as a substrate for bioelectricity production in microbial fuel cells (MFCs) without chemical pretreatment.
results_summary: The study found that OPW generated a maximum voltage of 0.59 ± 0.02 V, with pectin being a key contributor to stable current generation, while cellulose alone did not produce significant current. Bacterial analysis revealed Pseudomonas as a predominant exoelectrogen in the anode biofilm.
population_specificity: Microbial fuel cells (MFCs) and bacterial communities (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (substrate used was orange peel waste without specified dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on stable voltage generation stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prebiotic potential of pectic oligosaccharides (POS) derived from orange peel waste by assessing their fermentation effects on human gut microbiota.
results_summary: POS from orange peel waste increased bifidobacteria and lactobacilli populations and produced short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) similarly to commercial fructo-oligosaccharides (FOS), though pectin fermentation resulted in lower butyrate generation.
population_specificity: Human fecal microbiota (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of microwave pretreatment and surfactants on orange peel powder (OPP) for enhancing the production of pectinase, cellulase, and xylanase by Aspergillus japonicus PJ01 in submerged fermentation.
results_summary: Microwave pretreatment (630 W, 9 min, liquid/solid ratio 5) increased enzyme activities by 11.8–24.0%, while combining it with PEG 4000 (3 g/L) further enhanced activities by 30.3–40.4%. The study demonstrated a synergistic effect between microwave and surfactant treatment, improving enzyme production efficiency.
population_specificity: Aspergillus japonicus PJ01 (microbial fermentation system)
effective_dosage: Microwave pretreatment (630 W, 9 min, liquid/solid ratio 5); PEG 4000 (3 g/L)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of alcoholic orange peel extract (OPE) on streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy in rats.
results_summary: Treatment with OPE (200 mg/kg) improved renal function, significantly reduced creatinine, urea, and blood urea nitrogen levels, and decreased tubulointerstitial fibrosis in diabetic rats. The results suggest OPE may prevent diabetic nephropathy.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine effective methods for preparing cellulose nanofibers from orange peel and assess their potential applications.
results_summary: The study successfully prepared cellulose nanofibers (10–50 nm wide) from orange peel using pectinase and mild-physical blending, highlighting the importance of removing pectic polysaccharides and hemicelluloses. These nanofibers showed promise for use in food, pharmaceuticals, and filters.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on orange peel byproducts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of orange peel (OP) as an adsorbent for removing dyes (RYG, RG, RT) from effluents.
results_summary: Orange peel demonstrated favorable adsorption characteristics for dyes, with optimal conditions including a particle size of <0.4 mm and stirring speed of 300 rpm. The pseudo-second-order kinetic model best fit the experimental data for RG/OP and RT/OP, indicating effective dye removal.
population_specificity: Agro-industrial waste (orange peel) used for dye adsorption in effluent treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether orange peel waste could improve methane yield and biodegradability in mesophilic anaerobic digestion of sewage sludge.
results_summary: Mixing sewage sludge with orange peel waste (70:30 ratio) increased methane yield to 165 L/kg volatile solids and biodegradability to 76%, though inhibition occurred at higher organic loading rates.
population_specificity: Sewage sludge in anaerobic digestion systems.
effective_dosage: 30% orange peel waste by wet weight (mixed with 70% sewage sludge).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the trypsin inhibitory potential of flavonoids isolated from orange peel and green tea leaves.
results_summary: Rutin from orange peel showed the highest protease inhibition activity (75.4%), followed by catechin, hesperetin, and hesperidin. All compounds exhibited non-competitive inhibition, suggesting potential use in treating protein degradation-related pathologies.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: IC50 values provided (e.g., rutin: 16 ± 2 µmol L(-1))

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of orange peel essential oil microcapsules on oxidative injury in an acute otitis media (AOM) animal model.
results_summary: Orange peel essential oil treatment reduced serum and cochlea malondialdehyde (MDA), immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM) levels and increased antioxidant enzyme activities, indicating decreased oxidative injury in AOM rats.
population_specificity: Acute otitis media (AOM) animal model (rats).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of total flavonoids of orange peel (TFO) against adjuvant arthritis (AA) in rats and explore its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: TFO treatment (75 mg/kg and 150 mg/kg) reduced pad thickness, improved ankle joint pathology, and suppressed inflammatory mediators (TNF-alpha, IL-1beta, PGE2) and COX-2 expression in AA rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced adjuvant arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether orange peel products could reduce Salmonella Typhimurium populations in the gut of experimentally inoculated sheep.
results_summary: Orange peel supplementation numerically reduced Salmonella Typhimurium populations in the gastrointestinal tract, with significant reductions in the cecum at 10% OP. Palatability issues limited effectiveness at 20% OP due to reduced intake.
population_specificity: Experimentally inoculated sheep (n=24).
study_duration: 10 days before inoculation, followed by 96 hours post-inoculation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if orange peel and pulp supplementation could reduce E. coli O157:H7 populations in sheep.
results_summary: The study found that 10% orange peel supplementation significantly reduced E. coli O157:H7 shedding in sheep feces and populations in the gastrointestinal tract, with notable reductions in the rumen, cecum, and rectum. Both 5% and 10% orange peel diets showed significant effects, though the higher dose was more effective in the rumen.
population_specificity: Sheep (n = 24) fed a cracked corn grain-based diet.
effective_dosage: 0%, 5%, or 10% (dry matter basis, wt/wt) of pelleted orange peel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of orange peel waste for methane production under mesophilic and thermophilic conditions, focusing on D-limonene removal and anaerobic digestion efficiency.
results_summary: Pre-treatment achieved 70% D-limonene removal, and thermophilic conditions yielded higher methane production rates (0.27-0.29 L(STP)CH4/g COD) and biodegradability (84-90%) compared to mesophilic conditions, though acidification occurred at the highest organic loading rates.
population_specificity: Laboratory and pilot-scale anaerobic digestion systems.
effective_dosage: Organic loading rate (OLR) of 1.20-3.67 kg COD/m³·d at a solids retention time (SRT) of 25 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adsorption efficiency of mercapto-acetic acid modified orange peel for removing toxic metals (Cu2+ and Cd2+) from solutions.
results_summary: The modified orange peel showed high adsorption capacities for Cu2+ (70.67 mg/g) and Cd2+ (136.05 mg/g), followed pseudo-second order kinetics, and could be reused for over five cycles. The study demonstrated its potential as an effective adsorbent for toxic metals.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chemically modified orange peel (orange peel xanthate) in adsorbing Pb(2+) ions from solutions.
results_summary: The study found that sulfur-modified orange peel (orange peel xanthate) significantly increased Pb(2+) adsorption capacity by 150% compared to pristine orange peel, reaching 204.50 mg g(-1). The adsorption process reached equilibrium within 20 minutes and followed pseudo-second-order kinetics, with temperature having minimal impact on adsorption capacity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using solutions)
study_duration: Not applicable (batch experiments with 20-minute equilibrium time)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polymethoxyflavones (PMFs) from orange peel induce apoptosis in human breast cancer cells and how hydroxylation affects their proapoptotic activity.
results_summary: The study found that both hydroxylated and non-hydroxylated PMF fractions from orange peel inhibited growth and induced apoptosis in MCF-7 breast cancer cells, with hydroxylated PMFs showing greater potency at lower concentrations. The effects were linked to increased intracellular Ca(2+) levels, activating Ca(2+)-dependent apoptotic proteases.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cells (MCF-7 line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anaerobic digestion of wastewater from orange peel pressing, focusing on stability, methane production kinetics, and substrate biodegradability.
results_summary: The study found stable anaerobic digestion across varying COD loads, with methane yield coefficients of 295 mL CH4/g COD removed and 88.2% substrate biodegradability. Inhibition was observed at higher COD loads, reducing methane production rates.
population_specificity: Laboratory-scale reactor (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: COD loads of 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, and 5.0 g of COD (batch-fed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano essential oil could alleviate cold stress, improve well-being, and enhance growth in cattle by modulating the HPA axis and cecal microbiota.
results_summary: Oregano essential oil increased body weight by enhancing cecal microbial abundance and carbohydrate metabolism, reduced cold stress markers (cortisol, corticosterone, ACTH, dopamine), improved well-being by decreasing viral species, and enriched growth-related metabolic pathways. It also boosted antioxidants and lowered inflammatory factors.
population_specificity: Holstein steers (n=18)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary oregano essential oil (OEO) on antioxidant capacity, immune response, and intestinal microbiota in red swamp crayfish.
results_summary: OEO supplementation at 500 mg/kg increased antioxidant enzyme activity, upregulated immune-related genes, and altered intestinal microbiota composition without negative histologic effects. No significant differences were observed in phenoloxidase activity or malondialdehyde content between treatment groups.
population_specificity: Red swamp crayfish (Procambarus clarkii)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mixing orange peel (Citrus reticulata) with hydrocarbon-contaminated soil could enhance soil remediation by promoting microbial activity and hydrocarbon degradation.
results_summary: The study found that a soil-to-orange peel ratio of 92:8 significantly reduced total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPHs) by 69% after 15 days, increased bacterial counts, and improved microbial respiration activity. Other ratios also showed TPH removal and microbial activity increases after 60 days, though nitrogen and phosphorus consumption was limited.
population_specificity: Hydrocarbon-contaminated soil (58,000 mg kg(-1) soil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the analgesic and anti-inflammatory effectiveness of a combined preparation based on viper venom and essential oil, including optimal doses, routes of exposure, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The ointment version of the preparation reduced inflammatory pain by over 68% and decreased inflammatory edema by up to 36%, with cannabinoid and opioid receptors playing significant roles in the analgesic mechanism. No physiologically significant side effects were observed.
population_specificity: Murine (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano extract incorporated into a collagen hydrogel could enhance pressure ulcer healing in mice.
results_summary: Oregano extract significantly promoted wound contraction, improved skin layer reorganization, and reduced reactive oxygen species and nitrite production compared to untreated controls. It showed superior wound contraction effects compared to propolis extract.
population_specificity: Mice with induced pressure ulcers.
effective_dosage: 1% oregano methanolic extract in collagen hydrogel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oregano essential oil (OEO) nanoemulsion on the mechanical and antibacterial properties of PSE-like chicken protein isolate (PPI) film and its potential for food preservation.
results_summary: The study found that OEO nanoemulsion improved the film's mechanical properties, UV transmittance, water contact angle, opacity, water vapor permeability, thermal stability, antioxidant properties, and antibacterial activity. The PPI/OEO-2.5% film extended pork shelf life by 2-4 days.
population_specificity: PSE-like chicken protein isolate (PPI) film and pork preservation.
effective_dosage: 6% OEO nanoemulsion (with 12% Tween 80) and PPI/OEO-2.5% treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial activity of oregano essential oil (EO) vapor against food spoilage microbiota and assess its potential to extend the shelf life of leafy green vegetables.
results_summary: Oregano EO vapor demonstrated stronger antimicrobial activity than basil and clove EO vapors against common spoilage microorganisms. It extended the shelf life of kai lan but showed phytotoxic effects on butter lettuce and iceberg lettuce.
population_specificity: Leafy green vegetables (specifically kai lan, kale, butter lettuce, and iceberg lettuce)
effective_dosage: 10 µL oregano EO in a 1.8-L container
study_duration: Shelf life extension observed over 7 days at 25°C and 14 days at 7°C

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the growth and biochemical responses of oregano to drought stress and assess whether selenium treatment could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Drought stress significantly reduced oregano's fresh and dry biomass. Selenium treatment did not improve growth under drought but reduced oxidative stress markers (hydrogen peroxide and malondialdehyde) and increased chlorophyll a and proline content. Oregano also showed enhanced catalase activity under selenium treatment.
population_specificity: Oregano plants (Lamiaceae family) under controlled drought conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal mechanisms of oregano essential oil (OEO) against Penicillium expansum and its impact on the quality attributes of postharvest pears (Pyrus sinkiangensis).
results_summary: OEO demonstrated strong antifungal effects against P. expansum, disrupting fungal plasma membrane integrity and reducing decay in pears. It also preserved pear quality by reducing weight loss, maintaining firmness, and enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity.
population_specificity: Postharvest pears (Pyrus sinkiangensis) infected with Penicillium expansum.
effective_dosage: MIC (0.02%) and MFC (0.04%) against P. expansum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal activity of oregano essential oil against Fusarium species in quinoa seeds and assess its impact on seed germination.
results_summary: Oregano essential oil demonstrated strong antifungal activity, with a MIC of 1 μL mL-1, effectively inhibiting Fusarium growth. However, higher concentrations (10 μL mL-1) inhibited seed emergence and germination, while lower concentrations reduced fungal populations without affecting germination.
population_specificity: Fusarium isolates from quinoa crops in Boyacá, Colombia.
effective_dosage: 1 μL mL-1 (MIC), 10 μL mL-1 (inhibitory concentration for seed emergence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of microencapsulated oregano essential oil and cinnamaldehyde (COEC) on growth, immune function, intestinal health, and cecal microbiota in broiler chickens.
results_summary: COEC at 300 and 450 mg/kg improved growth performance, enhanced immune responses, improved intestinal morphology, and reduced pathogenic bacteria (E. coli) in broilers, with effects comparable or superior to antibiotic treatment (chlortetracycline).
population_specificity: Male Arbor Acres broiler chicks (one-day-old)
effective_dosage: 150, 300, and 450 mg/kg of COEC in feed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether oregano essential oil (OEO), alone or combined with benzoic acid (BA), could substitute for commercial coccidiostatic drugs in improving growth performance, gut health, and immune responses in broiler chickens.
results_summary: OEO significantly reduced pathogenic bacteria (Salmonella and E. coli) and Eimeria spp., enhanced Lactobacillus populations, improved growth performance, and modulated immune responses, with combined BA and OEO showing superior effects compared to salinomycin.
population_specificity: 1-day-old broiler chickens challenged with Eimeria species.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a protein/polysaccharide emulsion system to prolong the functional activity of Oregano essential oil (OEO) for food preservation.
results_summary: The optimal OEO Pickering emulsion (CBG-BC ratio 6:2) showed superior stability, encapsulation efficiency, and maintained antioxidant and antibacterial activities after 7 days of storage. Beef preservation tests indicated extended shelf life compared to control and pure OEO groups.
population_specificity: Beef samples (food preservation context).
effective_dosage: CBG-BC ratio of 6:2 (v/v) for emulsion preparation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of oregano essential oil (OEO) against malathion-induced toxicity, focusing on biochemical, histological, and enzymatic responses.
results_summary: OEO showed protective effects against malathion-induced weight loss, improved liver enzyme levels (ALT, AST, ALK-Ph), and reduced oxidative stress and hepatocellular damage. However, thyme essential oil (TEO) was more effective than OEO in enhancing CYP1A2 expression and mitigating toxicity.
population_specificity: 120 rats divided into six groups of twenty animals each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano essential oil (OEO) delivered via mucin-based dissolving microneedles (muMN) could effectively treat hypertrophic scars by reducing scar thickness, collagen deposition, and TGF-β1 expression.
results_summary: OEO@muMN significantly reduced scar thickness, epidermal thickness index, collagen area fraction, and capillary density in rabbit hypertrophic scar models, while also inhibiting TGF-β1 and hydroxyproline expression. The formulation demonstrated good penetration, biocompatibility, and fast dissolution.
population_specificity: Rabbit hypertrophic scar models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano essential oil (OEO) could serve as an effective anti-toxic therapy to counteract the adverse effects of MLT exposure in rats.
results_summary: OEO significantly improved liver enzyme function, reduced hepatocellular damage, inflammation, and hepatic fibrosis, and preserved renal tissue architecture in rats exposed to MLT. It also enhanced body weight gain and final weight compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Male albino rats exposed to MLT.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight of oregano essential oil administered for 21 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize oregano EO-loaded keratin microparticles (OEO-KMPs) as a potential treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC) while preserving vaginal microflora.
results_summary: OEO-KMPs demonstrated stability, high encapsulation efficiency, and controlled release, completely inhibiting planktonic growth of C. albicans and eradicating mature biofilms in vitro. In vivo, a single application reduced C. albicans growth while maintaining Lactobacillus species.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice infected with C. albicans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano extract could counteract growth inhibition caused by heat stress in broilers and improve gut health, antioxidant activity, and tight junction protein expression.
results_summary: Oregano extract at 50 mg/kg improved growth performance, feed utilization, digestive enzyme activity, and intestinal integrity-related gene expression in heat-stressed broilers, while also reducing oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Male broiler chickens exposed to heat stress.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg of oregano extract in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the ability of Mexican oregano essential oil fractions to inhibit the growth and motility of Gram-negative bacteria associated with urinary tract infections.
results_summary: Fractionated oregano inhibited bacterial growth and reduced motility, with Fraction 4 showing the highest growth reduction (MBC values 0.002–23.7 mg/mL). Motility reduction ranged from 92–81% for P. vulgaris, 90–83% for E. coli, and 100–8.9% for P. aeruginosa, attributed to high Carvacrol and Thymol content.
population_specificity: Gram-negative bacteria (Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris).
effective_dosage: MBC values ranged from 0.002 to 23.7 mg/mL (specific dosing frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether oregano essential oil (OEO) could mitigate the negative effects of high-inclusion soybean meal diets in zebrafish, focusing on growth performance and inflammation.
results_summary: OEO supplementation at 2% and 3% improved growth performance (weight, feed conversion ratio, and total length) compared to the soybean-only diet, though inflammation-related gene expression did not significantly differ. The 3% OEO group showed results comparable to the fish meal-based diet.
population_specificity: Zebrafish

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effect and mechanism of oregano essential oil (OEO) on *Listeria monocytogenes*, including biofilm removal and reduction of hemolytic activity.
results_summary: OEO demonstrated strong inhibitory effects against *L. monocytogenes*, reducing bacterial counts below detection limits, decreasing biofilm coverage by 62.03%, and lowering hemolytic activity to 24.6%. Molecular docking suggested carvacrol and thymol as potential active components.
population_specificity: *Listeria monocytogenes* (in vitro and in minced pork)
effective_dosage: 0.03% (v/v) MIC, 3/2 MIC (30 min), 15 MIC (minced pork), 1/8 MIC (hemolytic activity)
study_duration: 30 minutes (planktonic bacteria), unspecified for biofilm and minced pork

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of oregano essential oil (OEO) as a natural substitute for traditional veterinary drugs, focusing on its antibacterial, antioxidant, and growth-promoting effects in livestock.
results_summary: The study found that OEO exhibits broad-spectrum antibacterial activity, improves animal growth performance and health, and shows good bioavailability in pharmacokinetic studies. It also suggests OEO can reduce disease occurrence and avoid issues like drug residues and resistance associated with traditional veterinary drugs.
population_specificity: Livestock and veterinary applications (specific animal species not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the growth patterns of S. Enteritidis and S. Typhimurium in ready-to-eat smoked turkey under different storage conditions and packaging methods.
results_summary: The study found that storage at 0 and 5°C combined with MAP or MAPEO inhibited pathogen growth, while higher temperatures (10 and 15°C) allowed minor bacterial growth. MAPEO achieved pathogen elimination after 80 days at low temperatures.
population_specificity: Ready-to-eat smoked turkey meat products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the toxicity of oregano essential oil (OEO) on BeWo cells and T. gondii tachyzoites and evaluate its effectiveness in in vitro infection models.
results_summary: OEO showed low cytotoxicity on BeWo cells and significantly reduced T. gondii viability, decreasing intracellular proliferation by 84% at 50 μg/mL. Mechanistic studies revealed increased ROS levels, mitochondrial depolarization, and necrotic processes.
population_specificity: In vitro study using BeWo cells and T. gondii tachyzoites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of oregano oil against CCl4-induced liver injury.
results_summary: Both low and high doses of oregano oil showed protective effects against liver damage, improved protein synthesis, and reduced cytogenetic changes. High doses were more effective in protecting RBCs and reducing platelet aggregation but had weaker effects on hemoglobin synthesis and immune response.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal study implied by dosage units).
effective_dosage: Low dose (20 mg/kg) and high dose (60 mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oregano essential oil (OEO) supplementation could promote gastrointestinal tract development, enhance immune function, and regulate rumen microbiota in calves.
results_summary: OEO supplementation significantly increased calf weight gain, serum immunoglobulin levels (IgA, IgM), rumen microbial diversity, and enriched metabolic pathways, with 8g/day showing notable effects on microbiota regulation.
population_specificity: 70-day-old healthy Holstein male calves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy of Oreganum vulgare L. essential oil (OVO) vapors against pathogens and spoilage bacteria on various food-contact surfaces.
results_summary: OVO demonstrated broad antibacterial effects, eliminating viable cells on stainless steel, polypropylene, and glass surfaces contaminated with bacterial pathogens, except for Sta. aureus DSM 799 on glass. The addition of beef extract reduced Sta. aureus viability by over 5 log cfu coupon-1 on polypropylene and glass, while stainless steel showed no viable cells.
population_specificity: Bacterial pathogens and spoilage bacteria on food-contact surfaces.
effective_dosage: Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) values ranged from 94 to 754 µg cm-3 air.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal activity of oregano plant extract and essential oil against Candida albicans and their influence on virulence factors.
results_summary: Oregano plant extract and essential oil demonstrated high antifungal activity, inhibiting biofilm formation, extracellular phospholipase production, and germ tube formation at relatively low concentrations. The essential oil was particularly effective, reducing germ tube formation by up to 100%.
population_specificity: Candida albicans isolates (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Plant extract MIC 4.9–14.1 mg/mL; essential oil MIC 0.25–0.4 mg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nephroprotective effects of oregano essential oil and its constituents (thymol and carvacrol) against L-arginine-induced kidney damage by assessing inflammatory and tissue damage markers.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with oregano essential oil, thymol, and carvacrol prevented increases in kidney damage markers (urea, creatinine, NGAL, KIM-1) and reduced inflammation-related parameters (TNF-α, nitric oxide, myeloperoxidase activity). Histopathological findings supported these biochemical improvements, suggesting anti-inflammatory, antiradical, and antiapoptotic mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of oregano essential oil (OEO) on intestinal health indicators and antimicrobial resistance in piglets as an alternative to zinc oxide.
results_summary: OEO at 1.2% showed results similar or superior to zinc oxide in improving intestinal morphometry and microbiota balance, with reduced resistance in E. coli strains. High doses of OEO and its combination with purple garlic powder yielded the best outcomes.
population_specificity: Piglets weaned at 21 days of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of steam sterilization, gamma-irradiation, UV-irradiation, and ozonation on microbial inactivation, pyrrolizidine alkaloid degradation, and volatile compound profiles in oregano.
results_summary: Steam sterilization and gamma-irradiation were most effective in microbial inactivation, while ozone treatment significantly reduced pyrrolizidine alkaloid levels. These treatments also altered the volatile compound composition of oregano.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or lab-based study on oregano samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment methods described, not dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor mechanism of Oregano essential oil (OEO) in breast cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7).
results_summary: OEO demonstrated strong antioxidant capacity and reduced viability in breast cancer cells, inducing cell death via caspase activation and mitochondrial dysfunction. The effect was attributed to the combined action of multiple OEO constituents, suggesting potential for breast cancer treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro study using MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oregano essential oil on the quality, stability, and safety of pâtés made from tilapia filleting residues during storage.
results_summary: Oregano essential oil improved lipid and protein oxidation stability, maintained sensory acceptance, and reduced undesirable biogenic amines without negatively affecting texture. Higher doses (1400 ppm) showed better oxidative stability.
population_specificity: Pâté formulations stored at 4°C.
effective_dosage: 600 ppm, 1000 ppm, and 1400 ppm oregano essential oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oregano essential oil on growth performance, intestinal morphology, and cecal microbial composition in pullets.
results_summary: Oregano essential oil supplementation significantly improved villus height/crypt depth ratios and increased microbial richness in pullets, indicating positive effects on gut health. The gut microbial communities of the oregano-supplemented group were distinctly different from the control group.
population_specificity: Hy-Line Brown chicks (pullets aged 0-18 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oregano essential oil (OEO) and its terpene compounds (carvacrol and thymol) in inhibiting Acinetobacter baumannii biofilm formation and motility.
results_summary: OEO, carvacrol, and thymol significantly reduced A. baumannii biofilm biomass and covered area, with carvacrol showing the highest efficacy (95% reduction). Sub-inhibitory concentrations also reduced biofilm formation on stainless steel surfaces and inhibited twitching motility.
population_specificity: Acinetobacter baumannii biofilms (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentrations: OEO (0.6 mg/mL), carvacrol (0.3 mg/mL), thymol (2.5 mg/mL); sub-inhibitory doses used for biofilm reduction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antimicrobial activity of oregano essential oil (OEO) against Shigella flexneri and its efficacy in eradicating biofilm.
results_summary: OEO demonstrated strong antimicrobial effects against S. flexneri, reducing bacterial populations to undetectable levels in both LB broth and minced pork. It also effectively disrupted biofilm structure and reduced exopolysaccharide biomass.
population_specificity: Shigella flexneri in LB broth and contaminated minced pork.
effective_dosage: 0.02% (v/v) MIC, 0.04% (v/v) MBC in LB broth; 15 MIC in minced pork.
study_duration: 2 hours in LB broth, 9 hours in minced pork.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a poloxamer-based binary hydrogel containing Origanum vulgare L. essential oil (OEO-PbH) in treating fibroepithelial polyps (skin tags).
results_summary: The study found that OEO-PbH treatment led to drying and shrinking of skin tags, with a 20-30% reduction in lesions after one month and around 50% after two months. Histopathological changes included reduced thickness, fewer blood vessels, and lower cellularity in treated areas.
population_specificity: Individuals with fibroepithelial polyps (skin tags), particularly those in the fourth decade of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro antileishmanial effects of oregano essential oil (OEO) and its synergistic association with silver nanoparticles (AgNp) against L. amazonensis.
results_summary: The study found that OEO + AgNp exhibited a synergistic antileishmanial effect, inducing morphological and ultrastructural changes in promastigotes and reducing infected macrophages. The combination promoted ROS and NO production, mitochondrial depolarization, and apoptosis-like mechanisms to target both promastigote and intracellular amastigote forms.
population_specificity: In vitro study on L. amazonensis promastigotes and infected macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a formulation containing oregano essential oil (Origanum majorana) combined with geranium essential oil and thymol for controlling Rhipicephalus sanguineus sensu lato ticks on dogs.
results_summary: Formula A (2.5 g each of geranium, oregano, and thymol + 2% tween 80) demonstrated highly effective adulticidal, larvicidal, and ovicidal activity against ticks, with 99.3% reduction after the first application and 100% effectiveness with regular sprays every 35 days. Safety was confirmed by non-cytotoxicity in human cell lines and normal biochemical parameters in treated dogs, except for slightly elevated urea and AST levels.
population_specificity: Naturally tick-infested dogs.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g of oregano essential oil (combined with geranium and thymol) in 100 mL solution, sprayed every 35 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active components, potential targets, and mechanisms of action of oregano essential oil in treating bovine mastitis using network pharmacology and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study identified thymol, carvacrol, and p-cymene as major components of oregano essential oil, with potential targets including TNF, TLR4, and IL-6. Molecular docking showed strong interactions between these components and key targets, suggesting efficacy in treating bovine mastitis through pathways like PI3K-Akt and NF-κB.
population_specificity: Bovine mastitis (not human-specific).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antifungal activity of vapor-phase oregano essential oil (VP-OEO) against drug-resistant Candida species biofilms and its mode of action, as well as its effectiveness in a reconstituted vaginal epithelium model.
results_summary: VP-OEO demonstrated high antifungal activity, significantly reducing Candida species biofilms (>4 log CFU) and affecting membrane integrity and metabolic activity. The epithelium model confirmed VP-OEO's effectiveness against Candida infection.
population_specificity: Antifungal-resistant vaginal isolates of Candida albicans and Candida glabrata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal activity of oregano polar extracts and essential oil against itraconazole-susceptible and resistant dermatophytes, and to explore their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that oregano decoction (DEC) and essential oil (EO) exhibited strong antifungal activity, including against itraconazole-resistant dermatophytes. EO acted by targeting the fungal cell wall and plasma membrane, while polar extracts contained compounds like 4-hydroxibenzoic acid and luteolin.
population_specificity: Dermatophyte isolates from cats, dogs, cattle (n=28), and humans (n=2).
effective_dosage: Not specified (extracts prepared as infusions at 10 and 60 minutes, decoction, hydroalcoholic extract; EO purchased).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a lysozyme-oregano essential oil (Lys-OEO) antibacterial emulsion and evaluate its effectiveness against Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, as well as its stability.
results_summary: The Lys-OEO emulsion successfully inhibited the growth of E. coli and S. aureus, with optimal stability achieved at a 600 W ultrasonic treatment, resulting in smaller, more uniform particles and improved salt and pH stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Mass ratio of 1:1 (Lys to OVA) and 20% (w/w) OEO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HerbELICO®, an essential oil mixture containing Oregano, could effectively treat H. pylori infections and penetrate the mucin barrier.
results_summary: HerbELICO® demonstrated strong in vitro efficacy against H. pylori, with a minimum inhibitory concentration of 4-5% (v/v) and rapid bactericidal effects (10 min exposure). A customer case study reported a high eradication rate (up to 90%) and good consumer acceptance.
population_specificity: 20 H. pylori clinical strains from diverse geographical origins and 15 users of HerbELICO® dietary supplements.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human use; in vitro testing used 4-5% (v/v) concentration.
study_duration: Not specified for human use; in vitro exposure was 10 minutes.
